title: Triage scale
detail:
• Firs priority cases: Difficulty breathing, excessive bleeding, shock, allergic reactions, poison ingestion, abdominal distention, and hit by car; treated immediately upon arrival
• Second priority cases: Excessive V/D, seizures, possible urethral obstruction; stable patients that need to be monitored closely
• Third priority cases: Fever, ear hematoma, small wound; completely stable, nonurgent casts

title: Mentation status
detail:
• BAR: bright, alert, responsive
• QAR: quiet, alert, responsive
• Dull
• Depressed
• BAR
• QAR
• Obtunded (a decrease in responsiveness to environment)
• Stuporous (only responsive to painful stimuli)
• Comatose (unresponsive to any stimuli)

title: Ethylene glycol toxicity
detail:
• Found in antifreeze; sweet
• Lethal in small doses—1.4 mL/kg in cats, 4.4 mL/kg in dogs
• Absorbed thru GI tract and reaches highest level in blood in a few hours
• Leads to metabolic acidosis and renal tubular epithelial damage
• Metabolism leads to formation of calcium oxalate crystals, which build up to cause acute kidney failure in 24 hr in cats, 2-3 days in dogs
• Signs include intoxicated appearance, vomiting, PU, PD, low body temp, seizures; neurological symptoms appear w/in 30 min and improve after 24 hours
• Tx w inducing vomiting to minimize absorption (best if in 1-2 hr, not recommended after 4 hr), IV fluids to increase urine output and aiding excretion, administering 4-mehtylpyrazole to prevent metabolism of ethylene glycol (thru inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase), and sodium bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis
• Ethanol can be used if 4-methylprazole is unavailable

title: Chocolate toxicity
detail:
• Theobromine (more in dark chocolate) is toxic to dogs
• Signs include agitation, hyperactivity, V/D (at low doses); increased HR, high BP, arrhythmias (at higher doses); and neurologic signs and seizures at 60 mg/kg, which is found in an ounce of milk chocolate
• Can be fatal at 200 mg/kg (rare)
• Early tx vital
• Apomorphine used to induce vomiting and activated charcoal PO is used to block theobromine from absorption; IV fluids help w removal

title: Marijuana toxicity
detail:
• Dribbling urine is the classic sign
• Other signs include ataxia, mydriasis, hypersensitivity to movement and sound

title: Grape toxicity
detail: • Causes renal failure, but the patient will not exhibit any clinical signs for several days

title: Xylitol toxicity
detail:
• Found in sugar-free gum
• Causes hypoglycemia within 30–60 minutes of ingestion and liver failure in a few days
• Not ideal to have owner induce emesis at home due to risk of damage to esophagus and stomach with hydrogen peroxide, and the risk of aspiration, but it should be done if patient can’t be brought in w/in 30 min
• Charcoal doesn’t bind well
• Patient may present obtunded if the blood glucose is low enough
• Tx involves administration of IV dextrose for hypoglycemia, and monitoring of liver enzyme values and management of liver insufficiency

title: Ibuprofen/NSAID toxicity
detail:
• Life-threatening damage to kidneys and stomach lining
• Tx includes IV fluids for 48 hrs to promote diuresis and flushing of kidneys, as well as:
• Emesis followed by activated charcoal administration for absorption of residual drugs in the intestine (if ingested w/in the past hour)
• Gastroprotectants (sucralfate, pantroprazole) can prevent stomach ulcers and minimize risk of gastritis
• Misoprostol can have antidote-like effects and decrease risk of ulcer formation

title: Macadamia nut toxicity
detail:
• Toxic to dogs
• Causes weakness, ataxia, tremors, lethargy, depression, vomiting, hyperthermia
• Signs can occur w/in 12 hours

title: Raw dough toxicity
detail:
• Life-threatening emergency due to the rising process, which produces carbon dioxide and ethanol in the stomach
• Signs include severe bloating, vomiting, ataxia, depression, intense abdominal pain

title: Organophosphate poisoning
detail:
• Organophosphates inhibit acetylcholinesterase, causing acetylcholine accumulation and continuous stimulation of muscarinic, nicotinic, and CNS receptors
• Found in insecticides, flea and tick products (especially dog products on cats), agricultural chemicals
• Cats are particularly sensitive
• Clinical signs fall into three categories, with the patient starting at the first and reaching the third if not treated
• First category: Muscarinic—mnemonic DUMBELS (defecation, urination, myosis, bradycardia, emesis, lacrimation, salivation
Also SLUD—salivation, lacrimation, urination, and defecation
• Second category: Nicotinic (tremors, stiffness, ataxia, paralysis)
• Third category: CSN signs (depression, hyperactivity, anxiety, coma
• Tx w atropine for muscarinic signs and Pralidoxime (2-PAM) for nicotinic signs and to reactivate acetylcholinesterase

title: Topical toxins
detail:
• Most important treatment is to bathe the animal to remove as much toxin as possible
• Dawn dish soap can be used
• Patient should be seen by a vet asap after
• Should be done for cats that inadvertently receive dog flea products

title: Shock
detail:
• Condition in which the body does not receive adequate blood flow
• Leads to decreased perfusion

title: Circulatory shock
detail:
• Normal circulation requires normal BP and normal blood volume
• Circulatory shock results from a decrease in adequate volume of blood that is circulating in the body
• Can be hypovolemic, cardiogenic, or distributive
• Signs include fast HR, low BP, pale MM, weak pulse
• Can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, resulting in organ failure and death

title: Types of circulatory shock
detail:
• Hypovolemic shock: Occurs when blood volume is low due to traumatic injury resulting in excess blood loss
• Cardiogenic shock: Occurs when stroke volume decreases, leading to decreased circulating volume w normal blood volume—seen in heart failure
• IV fluids should be used w caution due to risk of causing a patient to go into heart failure
• Distributive shock: Occurs when issues w peripheral blood vessels cause blood to flow away from central circulation—mostly due to serious infection, anaphylaxis, heat stroke
• Fluid therapy essential
• Obstructive shock: Occurs when venous return to the heart is impaired; underlying cause must be treated

title: Septic shock
detail:
• Acute, severe bacterial infection causing multiorgan dysfunction, including poor perfusion of limbs, cardiovascular collapse, and metabolic changes like severe hypoglycemia
• Results in hypotension and poor organ perfusion
• Leads to hypoglycemia because inflammatory mediators, hypotension, and hypovolemia all combine to cause a decreased intake, decreased production, and increased use of glucose
• Can follow pneumonia, parvovirus, gastric or intestinal perforation, infected bite wound
• Signs include bounding (racing) pulse, bright red MM, fever, rapid CRT (less than 1)
• Hyperdynamic response (tachycardia, vasodilation, fever, and bounding pulses) early in septic shock causes hyperemic (red) MM

title: Compensatory shock
detail:
• Stage of shock in which patient is able to compensate for loss of intravascular fluid.
• Body compensates w tachycardia and peripheral vasoconstriction, both of which aid in maintaining normal BP
• Vasoconstriction causes extremities to be cool, and leads to prolonged CRT (can be normal too)

title: Decompensatory shock
detail:
• In the absence of medical intervention to shock, initial homeostatic efforts become ineffective, leading to decompensated shock
• Prolonged reduced tissue perfusion will lead to systemically inadequate tissue oxygenation and cellular dysfunction, resulting in multiple organ failures and possibly death
• In end-stage decompensatory shock, bradycardia will no longer respond to atropine

title: Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
detail:
• Inflammatory response that develops during shock, even in the absence of an infection
• Results in widespread vasodilation, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, marked increase or decrease in WBCs and platelets

title: HR in shock
detail:
• HR increases in early stages of shock to compensate for fluid loss and decreased oxygen delivery, maintaining blood flow to the heart and brain
• HR decreases in later stages when the patient is no longer able to compensate

title: Central venous pressure (CVP)
detail:
• Measures the right ventricular end-diastolic pressure
• Indicates heart’s ability to pump blood forward; anything that decreases this ability increases CVP
• Measured w a manometer
• Zero on the manometer should be level with the right atrium, since it measures the pressure at the right atrium (if it is held higher than the right atrium, water level will drop and provide a lower reading; if held too low, water level will rise and give an elevated reading)
• Tip of the catheter should rest just outside the right atrium, or in the cranial intrathoracic vena cava
• Normal CVP is 0 to 5 cm H2O; CVP of 5–10 cm H2O indicates hypervolemia, and CVP of more than 10 cm H2O indicates fluid overload

title: Central venous pressure in shock
detail:
• Cardiogenic shock occurs when there is a decrease in contractility of the heart, preventing it from pumping blood forward—leads to elevated CVP
• Hypovolemic shock is involves decreased vascular volume, meaning a decreased right ventricular end-diastolic pressure—leads to lower CVP
• Distributive shock is a result of an inability of the body to cause vasoconstriction in response to a decrease in blood volume or tissue perfusion; if blood vol if normal, CVP will be normal, if it decreases so will CVP
• Septic shock also causes vasodilation; since heart still pumps blood, CVP will be normal

title: Best and worst fluids for treating shock
detail:
• Isotonic crystalloids (Plasma-Lyte 48) will provide rapid intravascular volume expansion
• Hypertonic crystalloids and colloids will expand vascular volume; useful for patients that will not tolerate a large volume of fluids (like head trauma and heart failure)
• Small volume of hypertonic saline provides expansion by pulling fluid from the interstitial space
• Hypotonic fluids like D5W are least useful; should be used in the face of a free-water deficit or hypernatremia

title: Monitoring fluid therapy
detail:
• Easiest method is monitoring weight—1 L of fluids is 1 kg
• After patient is hydrated the weight should remain relatively the same; acute weight loss or gain (over several hours or days) while in hospital is likely caused by loss or gain of fluids
• Central venous pressure indicates heart’s ability to pump blood that returned from the body—if CVP is low, patient is probably hypovolemic and requires additional fluid therapy; if CVP is high patient is hypervolemic and fluid overloaded (invasive)
• PCV/TP, and urine output are also invasive and harder, but can be used for monitoring
• IV fluids should not be administered to an animal that has possible cardiac disease

title: IV vs. IO fluid administration
detail:
• IV is preferred method of fluid administration—access is simpler, faster, and more comfortable
• Intraosseous fluids can be administered as rapidly as IV fluids and they will enter the circulation just as quickly via the bone marrow sinusoids and medullary cavity—can be used when veins are not accessible
• Painful, requires heavy sedation or anesthesia; carries higher risks of infection (osteomyelitis), fracture, and extravasation
• Not for use in septic patients due to risk of worsening a life-threatening infection

title: SC fluids
detail:
• Isotonic fluids cause the least amount of discomfort and cause fewer complications (cellulitis, infection, or necrosis secondary to infection)
• Hypertonic and hypotonic fluids are irritating
• Colloids should not be given SC

title: IV catheters
detail:
• Butterflies are used for short-term, mostly for blood draws or administration of drugs; usually medial saphenous vein
• Over-the-needle-catheters are used up to 72 hours; cephalic vein most common
• Through-the-needle catheters can be used long-term; must be placed sterilely and in the jugular or lateral saphenous vein
• Intraosseous catheters are used mainly in critical patients, esp neonates w limited venous access due to vascular collapse

title: Benefits of IV fluid therapy
detail:
• Expansion of total body water w/in the intravascular and interstitial fluid spaces
• Diuresis (when volume administered exceeds maintenance needs)
• Electrolytes (patients mostly administered crystalloid fluids containing electrolytes)
• Calories (w added dextrose, or parenteral nutrition w addition of amino acids and lipids)

title: Blood products used for transfusion
detail:
• Packed RBCs (best option for life-threatening anemia)
• Fresh frozen plasma—albumin, coagulation factors (good for 12 months)
• Whole blood—contains RBCs, WBCs, proteins, coagulation factors
• Frozen plasma—thawed FFP, reduced factor V/VIII
• Synthetic blood substitutes
• Special IV set must be used; has fibers that remove clots and debris
• Can be administered IV or IO; intraperitoneal is the least desirable (slow absorption, risk of organ damage, risk of infection), but may need to be used; IM, SC, PO never used

title: Blood transfusion rates
detail:
• Should be completed in less than 4 hours
• Blood transfusions are given at up to 4 mL/kg/hr; plasma transfusions are given at up to 6 mL/kg/hr
• Boluses can be given in case of severe hemorrhaging
• Reactions include V/D and respiratory distress; most common sign is fever

title: Whole blood vs. packed RBC transfusion
detail:
• Whole blood provides RBCs, platelets, and coagulation factors, so a patient w hemorrhage secondary to anticoagulant rodenticide ingestion would be given whole blood to replace lost coagulation factors
• Patients w anemia resulting from an autoimmune disease or trauma, or suffering hemorrhage during surgery, require only RBCs

title: Cross-matching for second transfusion
detail: • Antibodies against RBCs develop w/in 5–7 days of receiving a transfusion, so a crossmatch should be done if the second transfusion is to be given in 5 days or more

title: Requirements for blood donors
detail:
• Dogs—can donate every 5 weeks
• 1 to 8 years old
• Weighing at least 55 lbs, allowing 450 mL of blood to be drawn
• PCV must be bw 37 to 55%
• Up to date w vaccines
• Cats—can donate every 5 weeks
• 1 to 8 years old
• Weighing at least 10 lbs, allowing 60 mL of blood to be drawn
• PCV must be bw 30 to 45%
• Up to date w vaccines
• Test negative for FIV/FELV
• Only indoor cats

title: Collecting blood from donors
detail:
• Animals will be sedated
• Put in lateral recumbency
• Jugular is used for draw, cephalic is used to administer replacement fluids at 3x the volume of blood
• 16-gauge needle is used for collection in dogs, 19- is used for cats
• Blood is collected in a bag w anticoagulant in dogs, and in a 60 mL syringe w 8.5 mL anticoagulant in cats, mixing often
• Pressure is applied to the insertion site for 2 min to avoid hematoma
• Vitals should be monitored constantly

title: Cryoprecipitate
detail:
• A blood product
• Derived from fresh frozen plasma, rich in key clotting proteins like fibrinogen, Factor VIII, Factor XIII, and von Willebrand factor (VWF)
• Used for a patient w von Willebrand's disease who is undergoing surgery or experiencing life-threatening bleeding ass w primary hemostatic dysfunction

title: Feeding tubes
detail:
• Orogastric tube: Flexible PVC tube placed in the mouth to go thru the esophagus into the stomach; short-term
• Can be bitten off, cause gastric reflux
• Nasogastric tube: Passed from the nostril into the stomach; longer-term
• Can cause irritation, swelling (rhinitis), epistaxis
• Nasoesophageal tube: Passed thru the nostril just to the thoracic esophagus
• Can cause irritation, swelling (rhinitis), epistaxis
• Esophagostomy tube: Surgical incision is made on the left side of the neck and red rubber or silicone tube is pulled into the esophagus, then the mouth, then turned around to be placed directly down the distal esophagus and sutured in place on the neck

title: Nasogastric tube placement
detail:
• Tube is measured from the nostrils to the 9th-13th ribs
• Topical anesthesia is applied to one nostril, followed by more after 2-3 min
• Placement must be checked by inserting a 1 mL saline into the tube—patient will cough if tube went into the lungs; alternatively gentle suction can be applied until stomach contents are aspirated
• Tube is capped to prevent aspiration of air into the stomach
• Location of tube must be checked before every feeding
• Finger placed over the tube during extubation will keep seepage into the pharynx or throat

title: Nasogastric and orogastric tubes
detail:
Nasogastric tubes
• Red rubber or polyurethane
• 5 Fr for animals under 5 kg
• 8 Fr for animals 5-12 kg
Orogastric tubes
• 12 to 18 Fr for kittens and puppies
• 18 Fr for dogs over 10 kg

title: Nasogastric tubes for equine patients
detail:
• Foals: 10-foot tube w 3/8 inch outer diameter, 1/4 inch inner diameter
• Yearlings: 12-foot tube w 7/16 inch outer diameter, 1/4 inch inner diameter
• Adult horses: 12–16-foot tube, 5/8 inch outer diameter, ~3/8 inch inner diameter
• Ponies or small horses: 12-foot tube w 1/2 inch outer diameter, 5/16 inch inner diameter

title: Orogastric tube placement
detail:
• No sedation or light tranquilizer
• Animal is in standing or sternal
• Tube measured from mouth to 9th intercostal space, and marked w a marker
• Speculum is inserted into the mouth, held tight by the restraining person
• Placement must be checked by inserting a 1 mL saline into the tube—patient will cough if tube went into the lungs; alternatively gentle suction can be applied until stomach contents are aspirated
• Feeding is followed by flushing w 6 mL water

title: Basic vs. advanced life support
detail:
• Resuscitation is classified as basic or advanced
• Basic life support includes chest compressions and ventilation, including intubation if possible
• Chest compressions should be started asap—before leaving for the hospital; pets should be transported asap even if they recover
• Advanced life support includes medications, defibrillation, and open-chest procedures

title: CPR
detail:
• Compressions are the number one life-saving action in CPR (not basic life support—ventilation is good, but not as vital)
• 100-120 chest compressions per minute
• Hands flat w one palm on top of other hand, elbows locked
• Compressions must be strong enough to compress chest 1/3 to 1/2 of normal width
• Compressions given over the widest part of the chest for deep-chested dog; for others they are given over the heart
• Ventilation provided every 6 seconds / at 10 breaths per minute if intubated, otherwise mouth-to-mouth breaths given at 2 breaths per 30 compressions
• More than 8–12 bpm will cause hyperventilation and hypocapnia, and decreased carbon dioxide will lead to vasoconstriction and decreased blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain
• Person doing the compressions is switched every 2 min
• Vasopressors administered every 5 min

title: Assessing outcome of chest compressions
detail:
• ETCO2 measurements of 10 to 15 mmHg indicate successful compressions
• ETCO2 will be zero during cardiac arrest since there will be no pulmonary blood flow; a sudden increase may indicate ROSC (return of spontaneous circulation)
• Pulse palpation and MM color aren’t reliable indicators

title: Oxygen supplementation
detail:
• Goal is to decrease hypoxemia, decrease the work of breathing (preventing the patient from tiring and going into respiratory arrest), and decrease the work of the myocardium (preventing the patient from entering cardiac arrest)
• Blow-by technique provides oxygen concentrations of around 35% if given 5L/min
• Oxygen cage provides oxygen concentrations of 50%
• Intranasal oxygen catheters can be placed inside the nose
• Measured from tip of the nose to the medial canthus of the eye
• Transtracheal catheters can be placed into the trachea to deliver oxygen at the highest rate

title: Breathing patterns
detail:
• Cheyne-Stokes: Respiratory pattern consisting of periods of apnea alternating w periods of hyperpnea; caused by an interruption in the regulation of breathing via CO2 levels
• Kussmaul’s: Deep, regular breathing pattern
• Paradoxical breathing: Occurs due to a disruption in the chest wall (broken rib) that moves in the opposite direction of the rest of the chest wall

title: Carbon dioxide levels and breathing
detail:
• Level of carbon dioxide in arterial blood controls depth and rate of breathing
• As carbon dioxide levels increase, a feedback mechanism increases the rate or depth of respirations
• As carbon dioxide levels decrease, rate or depth of respirations decrease

title: Orthopnea
detail:
• Patient sits or stands w the neck stretched out and elbows rotated away from the body in an attempt to decrease airway resistance to make breathing easier
• Indication that patient is tiring and should be watched closely for respiratory arrest

title: Assessing tissue perfusion
detail:
• Six parameters can be used to assess perfusion
• Mucous membrane color
• Capillary refill time
• Pulse quality
• HR
• Mentation
• Temperature of extremities

title: Splinting fractured limbs
detail:
• Stirrups are placed on the dorsal and palmar side of the foot and stuck together onto a tongue depressor to prevent sticking
• Cast padding is applied over the fracture to stabilize the leg
• A second layer of padding is applied, more on portions that may develop pressure sores from the splint like proximal and distal ends of the limb
• Elastic or rolled gauze is placed over to create a smooth surface for the splint to be placed
• Stirrups are folded back to secure the cast so bandage doesn’t slip down the leg
• A layer of roll gauze and then a layer of vet wrap is used to secure splint to the leg

title: Types of bandages for fractures
detail:
• Robert Jones: Any long-bone fracture, inc. fractures distal to the elbow
• Modified Robert Jones: Carpal, metacarpal, tarsal, metatarsal, phalangeal fractures; uses metal or plastic splint
• Ehmer sling: Hip luxation
• Spica splint: Humeral or femoral fractures
• Velpeau sling: Scapular fractures

title: Heat stroke
detail:
• Patient first must be cooled down w cool water or towels on the body and alcohol on the feet
• Cold water and ice not recommended to avoid vasoconstriction bc blood must remain on the surface to cool
• Aim is to cool down to 102.5F in an hour; if cooled quicker, body won’t be able to regulate own temperature
• Cooling stops at 102.5F to avoid shivering, which may lead to increased temperature due to muscle activity
• Oxygen must be supplemented via mask to improve tissue perfusion
• Room-temp IV crystalloids used to help fight dehydration

title: Frost bite
detail:
• Area is immersed in lukewarm water to dissolve the ice crystals that have formed in the tissue
• Massage should be avoided (may further damage)

title: Burns
detail:
• First-degree: Superficial, confined to epidermis; skin is reddened and painful, but re-epithelializes w/in 1 week w typical wound management
• Second-degree: Full thickness epidermal and partial-thickness dermal injury; epidermis is yellow-white, black, charred, may slough or leak plasma; will heal w/in 10-21 days, but severe ones may need surgery and cause systemic effects
• Third-degree: Full thickness injury of the epidermis and deep-layer dermis; thick, leathery, black dead tissue (eschar) that is insensitive to touch; requires surgery w eschar removal, debridement, and skin grafts/flaps if second intention healing isn’t possible; life-threatening systemic effects are likely
• Fourt degree: Involve tissue beyond dermis (muscle, bone, tendon); surgery required to prevent scarring that restricts movement; critical—intensive care necessary

title: Normal sinus arrhythmia
detail:
• Occurs when HR increases w inspiration and decreases w expiration
• Caused by a change of pressure in the thoracic cavity, which causes a mild vagal response that decreases HR
• Normal in dogs, horses, and cattle; rare in cats

title: Pulse pressure
detail:
• Pressure that allows to feel a patient’s pulse
• Difference bw systolic and diastolic pressures; reflects the force the heart generates each time in contracts, so it’s an indication of cardiovascular health
• If these numbers are close together, pulse will not be as strong; if they are further apart, the pulse will be stronger
• Large pulse pressure w a rapid rise and fall (aka snappy) can be a sign of anemia

title: Electrical shock
detail:
• Current that flows through the body is equal to the amperage, which is a function of voltage/resistance
• Resistance decreases w wet tissue (including mucous membranes—wetter the tissue, higher the damage
• A dry animal will not experience as much of a shock unless it chews the cord and the cord comes in contact w mucous membranes
• If the animal is wearing metal tags and electrical charge comes directly in contact w them, damage may increase

title: Cardiorespiratory arrest due to fluids
detail:
• Can be caused by air in the fluid line
• Bolus of air can be trapped in the vein or heart, causing an obstruction (embolus)

title: Rodenticides
detail:
• Rodenticides that cause neurologic signs
• Bromethalin causes cerebral edema, leading to neurological signs like tremors, seizures, paralysis (has the word “meth” which causes neuro signs in people)
• Rodenticides that cause hemorrhage (anticoagulants)
• Warfarin (first-generation), brodifacoum, bromadiolone, difenacoum
• Vit K antagonists; cause deficiency in clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, leading to bleeding—since VII will be depleted first, prothrombin time will be diagnostic
• Rodenticides that cause metabolic or systemic toxicity
• Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D₃) leading to hypercalcemia and renal failure and zinc phosphide leading to GI distress, cardiovascular and respiratory signs

title: Dystocia
detail:
• Active straining for >60 min w/out delivering a fetus, no straining for >4 hours when fetuses are present, weak contractions lasting >2 hours, or if the mother or fetuses are showing signs of stress
• A pup or kitten should not take longer than 5 min to move through the birth canal
• Profuse hemorrhage from the vulva is a sign, but green or black vulvar discharge is normal during parturition

title: Postures related to neurologic injury
detail:
• Decerebrate posture: Extreme rigidity of all legs, possibly w opisthotonus (arching of neck and back), often accompanied by stuporous to comatose mentation; indicates complete disconnect bw forebrain and brainstem—grave prognosis
• Decerebellate posture: Rigid forelimbs and flexed hindlimbs (all legs may be rigid too) w normal mentation; indicates severe injury to the cerebellum
• Schiff-Sherrington posture: Rigid forelimbs and flaccid hindlimbs when animal is on its side w ability to ambulate when placed on its feet, normal mentation; indicates T3-L3 spinal cord lesion

title: Cerebral perfusion pressure
detail:
• Pressure inside the cranial vault; controlled by tissue and fluid within the space
• As intracranial pressure increases, mean arterial pressure must also increase to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure and blood flow (and thus oxygen delivery) to the brain
• MAP is the blood pressure pushing blood into the brain
• ICP is the pressure inside the skull resisting blood flow
• Blood flow to the brain depends on the difference bw MAP and ICP— If ICP increases (due to edema, hemorrhage, trauma), CPP decreases; to maintain CPP, MAP must increase
• CPP = MAP – ICP

title: Most common cause of hyper- and hypocalcemia in dogs
detail:
• Hypercalcemia: Cancer/neoplasia
• Hypocalcemia: Pregnancy

title: Types of wounds
detail:
• Clean wound: Aseptic, such as incision for surgery
• Clean-contaminated wound: Surgical wound that enters a hollow viscus like stomach or bladder
• Contaminated wound: Caused by trauma or surgical incision into a contaminated area such as the colon
• Dirty-infected wound: Old, infected wound or caused by perforated viscera like perforated intestine

title: Tracheostomy
detail:
• Performed in case of upper airway obstruction (if Heimlich doesn’t work)
• Temporary tracheostomy tube is placed along the ventral midline in the area of the 2nd to 4th tracheal rings (bw the cranial and middle thirds of the neck)
• Shave from the mandible to the manubrium (bottom boundary of the thoracic inlet), wide enough to encompass each jugular vein
• Patient is positioned dorsally w legs pulled caudally

title: Thoracic drain
detail:
• Chest tube
• Used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest cavity
• Placed in the 7th, 8th, or 9th intercostal space

title: Feline aortic thromboembolism
detail:
• Most common cause is cardiomyopathy--turbulent blood flow in cardiomyopathy causes formation of thrombi, which breaks free, travels thru circulatory system, and becomes lodged in the distal aorta where it causes an aortic thromboembolism
• Aka saddle thrombosis
• Causes loss of the use of one or both hind limbs
• Signs include acute loss of motor in the hind legs, loss of femoral and/or dorsal pedal pulses, cyanotic pads or toenail beds

title: Myasthenia gravis
detail:
• Disorder of neuromuscular transmission
• Causes muscle weakness, esp. weakness after exercise that resolves with rest also common
• Megaesophagus is a common finding—signs include hypersalivation and regurgitation
• Acquired MG involves autoantibodies that attack acetylcholine NTs
• Congenital MG is inherited deficiency of acetylcholine receptors
• Tx w anticholinesterase inhibitors, which prolong the action of acetylcholine by blocking the enzyme that degrades it, and immunosuppressants
• Nursing care for regurgitation if megaesophagus present

title: Pain response in spinal injury
detail:
• Toe is pinched to assess response
• If patient can feel pain, it should respond by moving the pinched foot away from the pain and vocalizing
• Withdrawing foot w/out vocalization is a reflex; does not indicate perception of pain

title: Coagulation pathways
detail:
• Intrinsic pathway: Activated by damage w/in blood vessels; uses clotting factors that are already present in the blood, and is slower to activate
• Extrinsic pathway: Activated by tissue damage outside the blood vessel; injured tissues release tissue factor, which rapidly triggers clotting—faster to activate
• Common pathway: Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways converge into the common pathway, which leads to formation of a stable fibrin clot

title: Tests for bleeding disorders
detail:
• Activated clotting time measures function of intrinsic and common pathways
• Activated partial thromboplastin time tests intrinsic pathway— tests coagulation factors I (fibrinogen), II (prothrombin), V, and VIII–XII
• Prothrombin time tests extrinsic pathway—measures coagulation factors I (fibrinogen), II (prothrombin), V, VII, and X
• Buccal mucosal bleeding time checks platelet function; shows amount of time it takes for platelets to be activated and to form a primary platelet plug

title: Types of healing
detail:
• First-intention healing occurs when the edges of a wound are brought together and closed w sutures or staples (e.g. laceration)
• Second-intention healing: An abscess or puncture wound can be cleaned and flushed and then left to heal w no closure.
• Third-intention healing: A degloving wound is too extensive to close w/out daily bandage changes for several days until the tissue has developed a bed of granulation tissue; wound can be closed after

title: Diagnostic vs. treatment
detail:
• In emergency cases, initial treatment should address immediate, life-threatening problems
• Diagnostic test and measures should not be of concern at this stage
• For instance, in case of pneumothorax, oxygen supplementation, thoracocentesis, and covering the wound would be treatment; taking radiographs is a diagnostic so it is not urgent

title: GDV
detail:
• Occurs when stomach distends and then rotates
• Distended abdomen, restlessness, and nonproductive vomiting are classic signs
• Distended stomach puts pressure on the caudal vena cava, portal vein, and splenic veins, causing decreased blood flow to the caudal vena cava, which in turn causes a decrease in venous return to the heart—cardiac output and BP decrease
• IV catheter should be placed to treat shock
• Decompression of the stomach is important emergency treatment; accomplished by passing a gastric tube or by trocharization of the stomach (placing a needle thru the stomach to allow for release of air)
• Induction of emesis is contraindicated

title: Urethral obstruction
detail:
• Common in male cats
• Cats straining to urinate are often mistaken as straining to defecate
• Potassium will be reabsorbed back into the blood, causing hyperkalemia

title: Blood pH for dogs and cats
detail:
• Normal pH is 7.35 to 7.45
• pH < 7.35 is acidosis
• pH > 7.45 is alkalosis

title: Minimizing hemorrhage from the head
detail: • Pressure applied at the area adjacent and ventral to the mandible allows control of maxillary blood flow and hemorrhage to the head

title: Urine output rates
detail:
• Normal urine output on IV fluids is 1–2 mL/kg/h
• Urine output less than 0.5 mL/kg/h is anuria
• Urine output between 0.5 and 1 mL/kg/h is oliguria
• Urine output greater than 2 mL/kg/h is polyuria

title: Paraphimosis
detail:
• Emergency where the penis can't retract into the prepuce
• Applying hypertonic saline to the penis will pull fluid from the tissue, causing it to shrink
• Cleaning and lubricating the penis will make it easier to replace in the sheath
• Warm compress should be avoided because it will cause the penis to swell more

title: Tetanus
detail:
• Caused by the bacteria Clostridium tetani, which gains access to the body thru open wounds
• Bacteria produce tetanospasmin, a toxin that prevents the release of NTs that inhibit the firing of neurons, causing neurons to fire uncontrollably
• Muscles become stiff, head and neck may extend backward
• Other signs include salivation, stiff jaw

title: Drug administration during cardiac arrest
detail:
• IV administration is most effective
• with a catheter in the jugular preferred
• Intracardiac delivery is avoided due to risk of causing cardiac arrhythmias or damage to the heart and lungs  (last resort)
• Intratracheal possible, but not as effective as IV, and sodium bicarbonate cannot be administered via the trachea

title: Recommended dosage for intratracheal drug administration during cardiac arrest
detail:
• As much as 10 times the IV dose
• Should be diluted w 5–10 mL of sterile saline

title: Diabetes emergencies
detail: • A cat received insulin despite not having eaten all day, had a seizure—likely due to hypoglycemia; fixed temporarily by placing corn syrup, Karo, or honey on the gums to increase blood glucose, and brought in for exam (another dose of insulin must be avoided as it will decrease glucose further, causing hypoglycemic coma and death)

title: Hypoglycemia in septic patients
detail:
• Hypoglycemia is a common finding in septic patients
• Occurs due to decreased dietary intake, decreased production of glucose by the liver because of hepatic dysfunction, and increased consumption of glucose by cells

title: Patient position for best EKG reading
detail: • Right lateral recumbency

title: Positioning a patient w a flail chest
detail:
• A patient w a flail chest should be placed w affected side down to help stabilize the flail segment and allow the unaffected, healthy lung to expand
• Placing patient w affected side up will prevent healthy side from expanding fully
• A dyspneic patient should never be placed in dorsal recumbency
• Placing patient in sternal recumbency will allow lungs to expand but will not stabilize affected area

title: Treating seizures in cats and dogs
detail:
• Diazepam is the drug of choice to treat seizures in cats and dogs (first-line drug)
• Pentobarbital and levetiracetam are second-line drugs

title: Respiratory disease signs
detail:
• Increased inspiratory effort indicates upper airway disease; may result from foreign body, swelling secondary to an allergic reaction, etc.
• Increased expiratory effort indicates lower airway disease
• Overall increased RR and effort indicate lung disease
• Shallow, rapid respiratory pattern indicates pleural space disease

title: Pyometra
detail: • A release of endotoxin secondary to pyometra causes a decrease in the ability of the renal tubules to concentrate urine, which causes polyuria and polydipsia

title: Tick paralysis timeline
detail:
• Signs of tick paralysis appear 7 days after tick has attached
• Signs start to resolve in 24 hours, and completely resolve in 72 hours once tick is removed

title: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage
detail:
• Infusion of a fluid into the abdomen followed by its retrieval for lab analysis
• 20 mL/kg of sterile saline is infused, patient is gently rotated to allow it to move around, then removed
• Greater accuracy than abdominocentesis

title: ETCO vs. PaCO
detail:
• End-tidal CO2 allows monitoring ventilation (indicated by the CO2) without needing to perform a blood gas
• ETCO2 should be 2–5 mmHg less than PaCO2

title: PaO2
detail:
• Measure of how much oxygen is dissolved in arterial blood
• PaO2 of a patient breathing room-air should be five times the fraction of inspired oxygen—since oxygen of room-air is 21%, PaO2 would be roughly 100 mmHg

title: Lactate
detail:
• Lactic acid
• Produced by cells undergoing anaerobic metabolism as a result of lack of oxygen
• Hyperlactemia occurs if oxygen delivery to tissues and tissue perfusion decrease; most commonly occurs in hypovolemia

title: Hyperpnea vs. tachypnea
detail:
• Tachypnea: Increased RR
• Hyperpnea: Increased RR and respiration depth

title: Preload vs. afterload
detail:
• Preload: Amount of stretch on the heart—blood in the ventricles causes myocardial fibers to stretch; the more they stretch, the stronger the contraction
• Afterload: Amount of force/pressure the heart has to push against to expel blood from the ventricles; pressure required to open the aortic valve

title: Contraindication for jugular catheter
detail: • Patients with a coagulopathy (e.g. thrombocytopenia) should not have blood drawn from the jugular because bleeding would be difficult to control

title: Knuckling
detail:
• When a patient walks on the dorsal aspect of the paw
• Neurological abnormality
• Seen in horses

title: Mannitol
detail:
• Osmotic diuretic
• Decreases intracranial pressure by reducing blood viscosity; allows an increase in blood flow and thus oxygen delivery to the brain, as well as causing a decrease in the brain’s water content
• Crystalizes, so it should be infused w a filter to prevent crystals from being injected into the patient

title: Vestibular disease
detail:
• A sudden onset of balance problems caused by dysfunction of the vestibular system
• Central vestibular disease results from causes within the brain (e.g. neoplasia, infection, inflammation)
• Peripheral vestibular disease results from causes outside the brain (e.g. otitis interna and otitis media)

title: Hypersensitivity
detail:
• Type I hypersensitivity is related to mast cells and causes clinical signs related to allergies
• Type II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies attack normal cells
• Type III hypersensitivity is caused by the combination of antibodies and antigens; immune complexes are formed and inflammation follows
• Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed response to some sort of irritant

title: Whether or not to induce emesis for ingestion of different chemicals
detail:
• Hydrocarbons (fuels, petroleum, solvents) are life-threatening due to possibility of aspiration pneumonia, which can happen upon ingestion or when patient vomits—inducing emesis is contraindicated
• Lungs are very vulnerable to hydrocarbons; aspiration of <1 mL can lead to death
• The less viscous (thinner) a hydrocarbon, the more likely it is to be aspirated
• Emesis is beneficial for ingestion of organophosphates (pesticides, insecticides), salicylates (aspirin), and anticholinergics (some medications)
• The sooner emesis is induced, the greater the amount of material that will be removed--up to 75% removed if induced w/in 30 min; ≤60% if induced w/in first hour; minimally effective at 4 hours; not useful after 4 hours

title: Terms for muscle movement
detail:
• Fasciculations are irregular involuntary muscular movements
• Tremors are regular involuntary muscular movements
• Dyskinesia is any involuntary movement (muscular or not)
• Myoclonus is a sudden contraction of a muscle w immediate relaxation

title: Administration of potassium
detail:
• IV or SC only
• IM is very painful
• Hyperkalemia causes cardiac arrest by decreasing the ability of the heart to depolarize as well as repolarize, so supplementation should never exceed 0.5 mEq/kg/h

title: Pitting edema
detail:
• Swelling that leaves a temporary indentation or "pit" when pressed (vs. non-pitting edema, feels firm)
• Indicates excess fluid being trapped in tissues
• May be due to systemic issues like heart, kidney, or liver disease, or low protein
• Sign of fluid imbalance

title: Methemoglobinemia
detail:
• Iron in hemoglobin is normally in a ferrous state (Fe2+), which allows binding of oxygen
• If iron is oxidized, it will turn into ferric form (Fe3+); hemoglobin turns into methemoglobin and can’t carry oxygen
• Ferric form gives blood a brown color, turns MM brown
• Methemoglobinemia is caused by oxidative agents like nitrites, nitrates, chlorates
• Tx w methylene blue
• Acetaminophen toxicity in dogs, cyanide toxicity in ruminants

title: Pericardial effusion
detail:
• Pericardial sac surrounding the heart fills w fluid, preventing the heart from beating effectively
• Pulses become weaker w inspiration and stronger w expiration—inspiration changes pressure in the thoracic cavity and causes blood to flow into the right side of the heart, decreasing pulse pressure
• Heart changes position in the pericardial sac w each beat, leading to different heights of the QRS wave every time

title: Pericardiocentesis
detail:
• Removal of fluid from the pericardial sac to relieve cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition where too much fluid in pericardial effusion leads to cardiac tamponade
• Performed on the right side to avoid damage to lungs and coronary arteries
• Chest is shaved and surgically prepped from the 3rd to the 7th ribs

title: Cardiac tamponade
detail:
• A life-threatening condition in which fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac compresses the heart, preventing normal filling during diastole and reducing cardiac output and stroke volume
• Occurs in some cases of pericardial effusion
• Heart sounds may be muffled or not auscultated
• Other signs include increased venous pressure, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus (i.e. changing strength of pulses w inspiration and expiration)
• Pericardiocentesis is needed to relieve the pressure
• Most common in dogs, but same findings in other small species

title: Ketoacidosis
detail:
• Occurs when body cannot use glucose effectively and instead breaks down fat for energy, producing ketones—most common in diabetes
• Fat metabolism produces ketone bodies; these acidic substances lower blood pH.
• Three main ketone bodies: beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, and acetone
• Beta-hydroxybutyrate makes up the largest proportion of ketones in ketoacidosis contributes most to metabolic acidosis; not well detected by urine ketone strips, best measured in blood serum (reason why urine testing can underestimate severity)
• Acetoacetate is smaller in amount, but detected by strips
• Acetone is a minor ketone; produces fruity breath

title: Idiogenic osmoles
detail:
• Intracellular substances produced by brain cells to help maintain cell volume during hypernatremia
• In hypernatremia, fluid is pulled out of the cell in an attempt to equalize the concentration of sodium, causing cells to shrink
• Idiogenic osmoles are produced in response to increase cellular osmolality and pull water back in the cell
• Because brain adapts using idiogenic osmoles, rapid correction of hypernatremia is dangerous—lowering sodium too quickly can cause cerebral edema

title: Epistaxis
detail:
• Nosebleed
• May indicate head trauma, hemorrhage in the respiratory tract, rodenticide ingestion, presence of a foreign body, neoplasia
• Keeping patient quiet (sedation may be necessary), placing epinephrine in the nares (causing vasoconstriction), and administration of fresh frozen plasma (to replace clotting factors) will assist in decreasing bleeding

title: Lung sounds
detail:
• Crackles: Heard when alveoli that have collapsed pop open; indicative of pulmonary edema (fluid in the lungs) which will cause a collapse of the alveoli, pneumonia, atelectasis
• Muffled/decreased sounds: Heard when fluid or air is present in the ventral chest; indicates pleural effusion (fluid bw lungs and chest wall) or pneumothorax (air bw lungs and chest wall)
• Ventral decrease indicates pleural effusion since fluid settles ventrally
• Dorsal decrease indicates pneumothorax since air rises dorsally
• Wheezing: High-pitched musical sounds from narrowed airways; indicates asthma, bronchoconstriction, bronchitis
• Absent lung sounds: Severe pleural space disease like large effusion or pneumothorax
• Harsh lung sounds: Louder, rougher than normal airflow; suggest airway inflammation like early bronchitis
• Upper airway sounds: Stridor or stertor from the nose, pharynx, or larynx; Stridor or stertor from the nose, pharynx, or larynx; louder over the neck than the chest but louder over the neck than the chest

title: Stridor vs. stertor
detail:
• Stridor: High-pitched, harsh, wheezing sound caused by airflow through a narrowed larynx or trachea; common w laryngeal paralysis, tracheal collapse, foreign bodies
• Stertor: Low-pitched, snoring or rattling sound caused by obstruction in the nose or pharynx; common w brachycephalic syndrome, nasal disease, soft palate issues

title: Chemosis
detail:
• Swelling of the conjunctiva, secondary to edema
• Sign of fluid overload

title: Emergency c-section
detail: • Propofol does not cross the placental barrier and so is the safest induction agent

title: Extravasation
detail:
• Stop injection
• Try to withdraw as much medication as possible back thru IV catheter
• Administer saline, dexamethasone sodium phosphate, and sodium bicarbonate around the site
• Apply warm compress to increase circulation to the area

title: Activated charcoal
detail:
• Adsorbent—attracts materials to its surface
• Can bind to toxins, preventing their absorption and facilitating their excretion in feces
• Administered PO if animal ingests toxin at 1-2 g/kg
• Produced by heating wood pulp and washing it in inorganic acids; has a very large surface area—1 g equals 1000 m2, which is why it is so effective

title: Uroabdomen
detail:
• Presence of urine in the abdominal cavity
• Diagnosed by abdominocentesis
• Generally due to ruptured bladder, but abdominal effusion associated w trauma may be blood or urine
• Finding blood in abdominocentesis confirms hemoabdomen
• If fluid is clear, uroabdomen can be confirmed by comparing electrolytes—potassium and creatinine levels of the fluid w those of serum (uroabdomen is confirmed if ratio of abdominal fluid potassium and serum potassium is 1.9:1, or if ratio of creatinine in fluid and in serum is a 2:1)

title: Relationship bw magnesium and potassium
detail:
• Magnesium is an important cofactor for the ATPase pump, which is responsible for moving potassium in and out of cells
• When magnesium is low, potassium can’t move into cells and excessive amount of potassium will be excreted by kidneys
• If a patient receiving IV fluids w potassium still has decreasing blood values, magnesium levels should be checked

title: Hypothermia
detail:
• At 93 - 98°F, patient is alert, but tachycardic, and shivers
• At 86 - 93°F, patient becomes stuporous and bradycardic
• At 83 - 86°F, patient’s cardiac function decreases and patient becomes comatose, develops cardiac arrhythmias and muscular rigidity
• Below 83°F, patient goes into cardiac arrest

title: Hyperthermia
detail:
• When the core body temperature reaches 107°F, the body is no longer able to meet increasing oxygen demands of cells
• Permanent organ damage occurs

title: High-rise syndrome
detail:
• Describes a pattern of injuries, most often in cats, that results from falls from significant heights; include thoracic trauma, fractures, etc.
• Cats falling from seven stories and higher have less life-threatening injuries
• They reach terminal velocity (highest speed) at this point, and their vestibular system is no longer stimulated—they can right themselves (righting reflex) and relax their bodies so that they sustain less injuries

title: Tension pneumothorax
detail:
• Occurs when air is able to enter the pleural space but is unable to escape
• Pressure builds up and becomes greater than atmospheric pressure, causing the patient to become unable to expand the lungs
• Will not resolve w/out thoracocentesis to remove air

title: Performing thoracocentesis
detail:
• Performed by placing the needle cranial to the rib w the bevel up
• Veins, nerves, and arteries are on the caudal side of the rib; this helps avoid them
• After the needle is inserted into the chest, it is angled down so that the needle is lying against the chest wall and the bevel is facing the lungs
• This decreases the likelihood of lacerating lung tissue

title: Eclampsia
detail:
• Life-threatening drop in blood calcium levels that occurs in nursing mothers
• Aka hypocalcemia or puerperal tetany (milk fever)
• Emergency medical condition
• Mostly when puppies are 1 – 4 weeks old and mother is producing the most milk; can also occur before birth
• Causes muscle spasms (tetany) and hyperthermia

title: Calculating fluid requirements A 20-kg Springer spaniel is brought to the hospital because of anorexia and lethargy. Dehydration is estimated at 8%. The maintenance requirement of fluids is 66 mL/kg/day. To correct this dog's dehydration, how much fluid should it receive during the first 24 hours?
detail:
• Maintenance = 66 mL/kg/day = 66 mL×20 kg = 1320 mL/day
• Dehydration = 20 kg×0.08 = 1.6 L or 1600 mL
• 1600 + 1320 = 2920 mL

title: Intraperitoneal injection
detail:
• Performed 2 - 3 inches cranial to the umbilicus on the midline; any other area increases the risk of hitting a major organ
• Not performed often due to risk of puncturing an organ or causing peritonitis
• Most useful in neonates or for peritoneal lavage

title: Myelosuppression
detail:
• Condition in which normal bone marrow activity is decreased, resulting in fewer WBCs (esp. neutrophils), RBCs, and platelets
• One of the most common problems associated with chemotherapy
• Manifests as acute vomiting, diarrhea, and fever
• CBC will show neutropenia resulting from suppression of WBCs

title: Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s) signs and symptoms
detail:
• Most common signs are waxing and waning, including lethargy, decreased appetite, weight loss, weakness, and vomiting
• The decrease in aldosterone and cortisol ass w Addison’s will increase sodium excretion and decrease potassium excretion leading to hyponatremia and hyperkalemia
• Na:K ratio of <27:1 (normal is 27:1–40:1) confirms diagnosis

title: Blepharospasm
detail:
• Squinting
• Caused by irritation to the eye

title: Strike-through from laceration
detail:
• If there is strikethrough from bandage, bleeding is excessive and the laceration should be repaired
• If strikethrough occurs before laceration is repaired, bandage should not be removed to avoid disturbing any clots that have already formed; a second bandage should be placed over the original

title: Status epilepticus
detail:
• Continuous seizure activity or seizures occurring close together with no return to a normal mentation between each seizure
• Can cause hyperthermia, hypoxia, and neurological damage
• Life-threatening condition unlikely to resolve spontaneouslyI

title: Ventroflexion
detail:
• A posture in which the head and neck of a cat are bent downwards
• Classic sign of hypokalemia in cats
• Potassium plays an important role in maintaining the normal resting membrane potential in muscle cells

title: Electrolyte imbalances and associated clinical signs
detail:
• Hypokalemia causes muscular weakness
• Hyponatremia causes neurological signs such as seizures and coma
• Hypocalcemia causes muscle tremors and cramping
• Hypomagnesemia causes cardiac arrhythmias

title: Tumor lysis syndrome
detail:
• Occurs after chemotherapy for a highly responsive neoplasia like lymphoma
• Can occur w/in a few hours to several days
• Breakdown of the cancer cells causes a release of cellular contents that causes vomiting, diarrhea, depression, and signs of shock (pale MM, prolonged CRT, and bradycardia)

title: Cyanosis
detail:
• Blue MM
• Indicates RBCs not carrying adequate oxygen
• 5 g/dL of hemoglobin is required to detect cyanosis; correlates with a PCV/TP of 15%

title: Anti-prostaglandins
detail:
• Another name for NSAIDs
• Prostaglandins are involved in causing pain and inflammation associated w tissue injury—NSAIDs inactivate cyclooxygenase (COX), preventing the production of prostaglandins, so they are also called anti-prostaglandins

title: Defibrillation
detail:
• Sending an electric current of short duration thru the heart in an attempt to repolarize all cells at the same time (cause cardiac cells to depolarize and then repolarize in a uniform manner)
• Used when patient is in ventricular fibrillation, i.e. heart muscles in different areas contract independently of one another and coordinated pumping is lost
• If successful, SA node will resume control over depolarization

title: ABCs
detail:
• The ABCs of the primary survey should be followed upon arrival of the patient
• A = airway
• B = breathing
• C = circulation
• Respiratory system should always be evaluated first; airway should be assessed for obstruction along with respiratory rate, effort, and pattern

title: Fetal HR in foals
detail:
• Baseline bw 60 to 75 bpm in last week of pregnancy
• May go above 120 bpm or below 60 bpm in short periods, but recovers quickly
• Less than 60 bpm and more than 83 bpm are concerning if persistent

title: Eastern/western/Venezuela encephalomyelitis in horses
detail:
• Mosquito-borne viral disease
• Signs include head pressing, ataxia, circle walking, behavioral changes, depression, lethargy, tongue weakness, seizures, facial paralysis, generalized weakness, and blindness

title: Equine viral arteritis
detail:
• Viral disease transmitted via respiratory secretions and venereally
• Signs include fever, limb and genital edema, nasal discharge, conjunctivitis, abortion, lethargy

title: Potomac horse fever (equine monocytic ehrlichiosis)
detail:
• Rickettsial infection caused by bacteria of the order Rickettsiales (Neorickettsia risticii)
• Signs include abortion, fever, colic, diarrhea, appetite change, laminitis

title: Diaphragmatic hernia
detail:
• Tear can allow abdominal organs to herniate into the chest cavity
• Signs include lack of appetite, lethargy, muffled heart and lung sounds, dyspnea, tachypnea; gut sounds may be heard in thoracic cavity if a portion of GI tract herniates
• Dx w radiographs or ultrasound
• Tx includes stabilizing dyspnea w oxygen therapy, sedation and anxiolytic (butorphanol), and corrective surgery

title: Survey radiography
detail:
• Most comprehensive choice for routine assessment of thoracic trauma following a hit by car—quick and noninvasive
• Assesses musculoskeletal structures, pleural space, cardiorespiratory tissues, diaphragmatic integrity
• Ultrasound can’t evaluate bones and doesn’t completely assess lungs

title: Opisthotonus
detail:
• Severe spasm causing the body to hyperextend backward and stiffen
• Top of head can touch spine on the lower back
• Sign of neurologic disease—most commonly seen w blunt trauma to the head or other trauma, but can also be due to a disease of the cerebellum (tumor, infection, inflammation)
• Indicates a complete lack of communication between brain stem and forebrain in cats and dogs, so they are stuporous or comatose
• Grave prognosis

title: Urinary catheterization of camelids
detail:
• Almost impossible in males due to a recess located dorsally at the ischial arch
• Females easy—place finger in vulva to locate external urethral opening, insert 5 Fr red rubber or polypropylene catheter
• Important to move dorsally (dorsal approach) to avoid entering the diverticulum
• Advance 25 cm into the bladder

title: Sinus bradycardia
detail:
• Occurs when sinus node’s rhythm is lower than normal
• Usually secondary to increase in vagal tone, or systemic disease like hypothermia or hypothyroidism
• Also common w drug intoxication and overdose

title: Pulmonary edema
detail:
• Fluid w/in lung tissue due to left-sided CHF, electrocution, smoke inhalation, strangulation, airway obstruction, fluid overload, and some neoplasias
• Cardiogenic pulmonary edema is caused by an increase in hydrostatic pulmonary pressure (i.e. pressure from blood w/in pulmonary capillaries) from heart failure—increased pressure causes fluid to leak into lung tissue
• Noncardiogenic pulmonary edema is caused by a decrease in plasma oncotic pressure or increase in capillary membrane permeability
• Plasma oncotic pressure is the force exerted by proteins in blood plasma that helps retain fluid in blood vessels; a decrease in this pressure leads to fluid leak into lungs
• Capillary membrane permeability may decrease due to inflammation or injury, allowing fluid to escape into lung tissue

title: Pulmonary edema vs. pleural effusion vs. pneumothorax
detail:
• Pulmonary edema refers to fluid w/in the lungs
• Wheezing and crackles
• Pleural effusion refers to fluid bw the lungs and the body wall
• Muffled or decreased lung sounds
• Pneumothorax refers to air trapped bw the lungs and the body wall
• Muffled or decreased lung sounds

title: Heart failure
detail:
• Heart’s pumping pressure decreases, leading to backward or restricted flow—creates increased pressure resulting in fluid moving out of interstitial space into the alveoli (pulmonary edema)
• Signs include wheezing, crackles, pale or cyanotic gums, coughing
• CHF can lead to either pulmonary edema or pleural effusion

title: Parvovirus
detail:
• Viral infection; spread thru fecal-oral transmission
• Signs include V/D, fever, dehydration
• Tachycardia may occur as body tries to combat fluid imbalance resulting from V/D and dehydration
• Causes leukopenia
• Secondary sepsis is common, will also lead to tachycardia
• Tx includes treating dehydration and malnutrition, controlling nausea/vomiting, and antibiotics to prevent secondary infections
• Patients who are treated will have lifetime immunity

title: Vagal event
detail:
• Response triggered by stimulation of the vagus nerve
• Can be caused by stress, pain, etc.
• Leads to sudden decrease in HR and BP
• Lack of blood flow to brain and other organs result in dizziness, nausea, syncope

title: Pulse ox readings
detail:
• 95 to 100 is normal
• Below 92 indicates serious illness
• Requires immediate supplemental oxygen and diagnostic assessment to determine cause
• True for all animals

title: BCS in goats
detail:
• BCS is evaluated in goats based on the visibility of vertebrae and ribs, fat mobility, and presence of fat or muscle bw ribs and bones
• Ideal is 3—thick, barely movable sternal fat, difficulty feeling chondrosternal joints, sufficient tissue covering lumbar vertebrae, inability to palpate articular processes of the spinal transverse processes, and a minimally prominent back bone

title: Chondrosternal joints
detail:
• Connections bw the ribs’ cartilage and the sternum
• In BCS evaluation, easily felt joints indicate low body fat

title: pH of cow’s rumen content
detail:
• Normal is 5.5 (for cows on high-grain diets) to 7
• Should be relatively neutral at 7
• Will be acidic (e.g. 6.5) in rumen acidosis—should be corrected w oral magnesium oxide and transfaunation from a donor; feed should be reassessed

title: Collapsing trachea
detail:
• Chronic disease in small breed dogs
• Slowly progressive, but can become life-threatening
• Can be treated w antitussives, bronchodilators, corticosteroids
• Neck leads should be avoided
• Weight loss can help
• Oxygen therapy is necessary once patient is in respiratory distress
• Surgical correction is rarely necessary, but involves creating and implanting custom prosthetic tracheal rings

title: Blood collection for arterial blood gas
detail:
• Needs a minimum of 1 mL of blood
• No air should get into the syringe system
• Temp must be taken at time of collection bc analysis is usually corrected based on temp
• Sample should be placed on ice immediately and run as quickly as possible—ideal is w/in 10 min but can work upto 90 min if stored on ice and air-tight
• Rubber stopper can be placed on syringe to prevent air from entering

title: Crash cart
detail: • Expiration dates must be checked after every use, and once a month at a minimum

title: Respiratory arrest in horses
detail:
• 4 to 6 bpm necessary to maintain normal PaO2
• If ET tube not available, 10-foot Tygon tube w ½-inch diameter can be used for nasotracheal intubation
• 100% oxygen should be used and flow rate should be adjusted to permit chest expansion every 2-3 seconds
• Bag compressions should be bw 20 to 40 cm H2O

title: Blood types in horses
detail:
• No common equine blood type, no universal donors
• There are 8 different major blood systems
• 7 systems carry 34 blood factors

title: Blood types in dogs
detail:
• Dog erythrocyte antigen (DEA)
• DEA 4 is most common—universal donor

title: Breech position
detail:
• Fetus is in a posterior position w hind legs retained and rump presented first
• Must be repositioned so that either the head or the legs are presented first for vaginal delivery to occur

title: Anisocoria
detail:
• Term for difference in the size of pupils
• Indicates intracranial disease, cervical spinal cord disease, or ophthalmic disease—all leading to neurologic signs

title: Aminophylline
detail:
• Bronchodilator
• Can be administered via nebulization in horses w respiratory compromise in emergency cases

title: Main arrhythmias ass w cardiac arrest on ECG
detail:
• Asystole: Absence of mechanical and electrical heart activity; treated w epinephrine (IV vasopressor)
• Pulseless electrical activity: Absence of mechanical heart beat despite evidence of electrical activity on ECG; treated w epinephrine, naloxone, or vasopressin
• Ventricular tachycardia: Rapid heart rate pattern indicative of impending arrest; treated w lidocaine

title: Mechanical ventilation
detail:
• Life-support technique that uses a machine to assist or replace breathing
• Extensive monitoring necessary
• Eyes should be lubricated, oral cavity swabbed out, catheters and tracheostomy tubes checked, ROM exercises performed, and patient repositioned every 4-6 hours

title: Brachycephalic airway syndrome
detail:
• Anatomical abnormalities lead to breathing problems and possibly GI and other diseases
• Often obese
• Have stenotic nares, i.e. narrow nostrils that restrict airflow
• Have elongated soft palates
• Many have tracheal hypoplasia, i.e. underdeveloped/narrow trachea leading to increased resistance to airflow
• Nasal turbinates commonly hypoplastic or abnormal in composition
• Chronically increased resistance to airflow due to all of the above leads to laryngeal saccule eversion (protrusion), tonsillar eversion, tracheal/laryngeal collapse, and syncope
• Higher risk of aspiration pneumonia
• May present w signs of upper airway obstruction—stertor, heat and exercise intolerance, dyspnea

title: Fetotome
detail:
• Device used to cut a fetus into smaller parts w wire to facilitate vaginal removal (i.e. fetotomy)
• Mostly used in large animals

title: Krey hook
detail: • Used to hold fetus parts for removal

title: Calf jack
detail: • Used to apply traction on obstetrical chains placed on limbs of the fetus for vaginal delivery

title: Seldinger guidewire technique
detail:
• Multilumen catheter insertion technique
• Required distance for catheter insertion is measured so that tip of the catheter lies w/in the thoracic cavity, cranial to the right atrium—measure from insertion site to caudal edge of triceps muscle
• Insertion site is surgically prepared and draped
• Local anesthetic recommended if animal is awake
• Sterile gloves, hat, mask, and gown recommended
• Distal port of the multilumen is identified as the port that terminates at the very tip of the catheter—the port thru which the guidewire will pass
• All ports are flushed w heparinized saline, and all but distal portal is capped
• Small incision is made w a blade, and the introducing needle or short ITN catheter is inserted into the underlying vessel
• Guidewire is threaded thru, followed by the multilumen catheter, which is sutured in place

title: Pulsus paradoxus
detail:
• Pulse weakens during inspiration and strengthens during expiration
• Often seen in cardiac tamponade due to impaired heart filling

title: Emergency drugs
detail:
• Epinephrine: Main drug to stimulate contractions; causes vasoconstriction by action on the sympathetic nervous system; used in asystole and pulseless electrical activity
• Vasopressin: Causes smooth muscle-induced vasoconstriction in the periphery
• Lidocaine 2%: Used to treat premature ventricular contractions and ventricular tachycardia; antiarrhythmic so not useful in cardiac arrest
• Atropine: Acts by blocking vagus nerve effects on the heart by accelerating electrical impulse transmission, so used in cardiac arrest secondary to vagal mediation, as well as for AV block and bradyarrhythmias

title: Feline asthma
detail:
• Inflammation and irritation of the broncho
• Causes bronchiolar constriction, increased mucous production, bronchiolar smooth muscle hypertrophy
• Triggered by allergens, fungal infection, etc.
• Tx involves bronchodilator to open up large airways, sedation for anxiety ass w difficulty in breathing
• Albuterol is used as bronchodilator
• Butorphanol is used for antitussive and sedative properties
• Long term management will involve corticosteroids (injectable in short-term, inhaled after)
